Shai Gilgeous-Alexander scored 39 points in 29 minutes.
Isaiah Joe added 23 of his 31 points in the first half.
Oklahoma City Thunder had a 36-12 run in the first half en route to a 70-43 lead.
Shai Gilgeous-Alexander outdueled Jalen Brunson as the Thunder rolled to a 126-101 rout of the Knicks.
Alexander played like an MVP, dropping 39 points in just 29 minutes.
A 3-pointer by Joe capped a 12-0 run by the Thunder to end the first quarter with a 14-point lead.
Boos started to rain on the Knicks toward the end of the first half after they could only cough up 43 points, their second-lowest scoring first half this season.
Oklahoma City extended it to as many as 30 in the second half to cruise to a West-best 31st victory in 37 games.
Alexander blocked Brunson in one sequence in the second half, which epitomized the kind of rough night the Knicks had at the hands of the Thunder.
Mark Daigneault expressed happiness for Isaiah Joe's performance, noting his confidence and consistency.
Isaiah Joe emphasized the importance of staying consistent and having confidence in himself.
Shai Gilgeous-Alexander praised Joe's shooting ability and predicted his slump would end.
Jalen Williams highlighted Joe's hard work and dedication in the gym.
Mikal Bridges emphasized the need to improve defense despite offensive struggles.
Tom Thibodeau highlighted the need for multiple defensive efforts.
Josh Hart mentioned the importance of executing and maintaining intensity.
Jalen Brunson acknowledged the potential of the Knicks' defense.
Karl-Anthony Towns noted that not all games will be perfect.
Thunder coach Mark Daigneault commented on Isaiah Joe's performance, saying it opened up the game wider than usual.
Isaiah Joe mentioned that the shots came within the flow of the game and offense.
Oklahoma City made it clear quickly it wasn't letting Wednesday's loss linger.
Coach Mark Daigneault had an easy game despite not feeling well and wearing a mask at times.
The Knicks were booed multiple times in the first half of perhaps the low point of their season, which featured an 0-for-9 night by Mikal Bridges.
New York coach Tom Thibodeau said after the beatdown, 'We got into a big hole right away. We started flat. Our defense wasn’t very good.'

Thibodeau owned the Knicks’ lackluster performance, saying, 'We have to be a lot better defensively, and it requires a lot more than what we did today. That's my responsibility. I gotta make sure we're ready to go.'

Thibodeau reflected, 'I always have the belief that we can do better no matter what we do. And so, when you fall short, you have to take a look and start with yourself, and we ask yourself, ‘What you could do better?’ And then you go from there.'

Thibodeau added, 'As a coach, that's what I have to do. As a player, that's what they have to do. And then we have to do it collectively. It's ‘We got into this together, we got to get out of it together.’
Oklahoma City's win stretched their lead to 31-6 at the top of the Western Conference standings.
Former Knicks backup center Isaiah Hartenstein, who left them in the offseason to sign a three-year, $87 million deal with the Thunder, returned to the Garden to a loud ovation and a video tribute.
Hartenstein helped Oklahoma City with six points, nine rebounds, six assists, two steals and two blocks in his first game back in New York since he left.
Karl-Anthony Towns saw his 32nd double-double (23 points and 10 rebounds) of the season go down the drain with the Knicks’ 14th loss in 39 games.
The Knicks remained third in the Eastern Conference despite the loss.
The Knicks have more firepower now after their couple of big trades in the offseason to land Towns and Bridges. But it cost them their depth and the Thibodeau signature defense.
Entering the midway point of the season, their defense currently ranks 15th, six rungs below where they finished last season with less talent.
Giannis Antetokounmpo and the Milwaukee Bucks will provide another litmus test for the Knicks on Sunday (Monday Manila time).
